Air Headquarters, Iraq is negotiating a contract with Messrs. Cray, Mackenzie & Co. Ltd., Bahrain for the landing and shipping of Service cargo and personnel at Bahrain. 2. The rates quoted for cargo are stated to be controlled by the Government of Bahrain and are From Manama Anchorage to Manama Jetty (i) General Cargo Rs.7/8/- per ton (iij Bag Cargo Rs.f?/-/- per ton 3. The question of the admissibility of the rates quoted raises several points that require elucidation, and it would be appreciated if you would supply the answers to the following A. For what purpose does the Bahrain Government control the landing rates, how far these rates are artificial (for political or other purposes) and how far they bear a reasonable relationship to the actual cost per ton for the work performed ? If it is substantiated that these rates are artificial and provide, in effect, a substantial unnecessary profit to the agent B. Is the Bahrain Government prepared to negotiate any special landing rates in respect of R.A.F. and other Military cargo ? It is also advised that of the controlled landing rates payable to the agents, an amount of 5/o is payable by the agents to the Bahrain Government by way of indirect import tax C. Whether this is normally met by the agents out of the controlled commercial rates or is added to their bill as an extra ? D. Whether the Bahrain Government is prepared to waive the in respect of all R.A.F. cargo landed or shipped and if not, whether they have any legal right to insist on its payment ? In addition, an 8 annas stamp fee is levied by the customs authority in respect of every bill of entry E. Whether the R.A.F. is exempt from this local stamp duty in respect of imports ? 4 HoBoM* s Political Agent, The Agency, BAHRAIN. (P.R.M.W TT.T.TA MS) Wing Commander Air Staff Liaison Officer. The Bahrain Government controls the landing rates because it has granted a monopoly to Gray Mackenzie & Co., Ltd., for the landing of cargo from ships belonging to lines for which that Company are agents. Clearly, if these rates were not so controlled the tendency would be for the monopolist to charge excessively. It is not possible &SLKxk (without full access to Messrs. Gray Mackenzies* accounts) to say, in any exact way, what relationship the present charges per ton bear to the cost of the work performed. All that can be said is that the Bahrain Government consents to raising of the charges with the greatest reluctance and that they are jealously scrutinised by the local mercantile community. B. The Bahrain Government have recently consented to an increase in the landing charges, equating them with the rates given in paragraph 2 of your letter. These rates were agreed upon, it was stated, to cover the actual costs of landing cargo and to allow a reasonable profit. It is possible that the Bahrain Government would be prepared to allow special landing rates for R.A.F. and Military cargo provided Messrs. Gray Mackenzie also agreed to such rates. C. The 5% is a royalty and it has a right to impose it. E. The R.A.F. is not exempt from the local stamp duty in respect of imports. 3. The delay in replying to your letter is regretted. ATTESTED. titleInfo.title: 'File 9/36 Contract between Air Headquarters and Gray Mackenzie Limited'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically. There are file notes at the end, on folio 6. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 8; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence exchanged between the Political Agent at Bahrain and the Office of the Air Staff Liaison Officer at Bahrain regarding a contract between Air Headquarters Iraq and Gray Mackenzie & Co for embarkation services, landing and shipping service cargo and personnel at Bahrain.
